fields.description: At the moment, we error out on {{coerce_timestamps='ms'}} on {{pyarrow.parquet.write_table}} if the data contains a timestamp that would loose information when converted to milliseconds. In a lot of cases the user does not care about this granularity and rather wants the comfort functionality that the timestamp are stored regardlessly in Parquet. Thus we should provide an option to ignore the error and do the lossy conversion.
fields.summary: [Python] Provide an option to convert on coerce_timestamps instead of error

comments.body:
We have been hitting this, here is a very simple repro:
{code:java}
from datetime import datetime
import pandas as pd

dt = datetime(day=1, month=1, year=2017, hour=1, minute=1, second=1, microsecond=1)
values = [(dt,)]
df = pd.DataFrame.from_records(values, columns=['testname'])
df.to_parquet('/tmp/repro.parquet', coerce_timestamps='ms')
{code}
This fails with:
{code:java}
Traceback (most recent call last):
<SNIP>
File "pyarrow/_parquet.pyx", line 922, in pyarrow._parquet.ParquetWriter.write_table
File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 81, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
pyarrow.lib.ArrowInvalid: Casting from timestamp[ns] to timestamp[ms] would lose data: 1483232461000001000
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
{code}
[~farnoy] the first thing I would track down is if write_table is passing kwargs through to the right place.

And here's a test asserting as much through write_table: [https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/f70dbd1dbdb51a47e6a8a8aac8efd40ccf4d44f2/python/pyarrow/tests/test_parquet.py#L846]

 

EDIT: Although it only tests microsecond truncation, not nanosecond...
I think it works if I specify the arrow schema in `timestamp('us')` resolution (was doing ms here before). But I have a different, unrelated problem so I can't confirm 100%. Thanks for the help
